newsitem.title: USA: U.S. deficit up in July but trend is down.
newsitem.headline: U.S. deficit up in July but trend is down.

text.p: The government's spending deficit doubled in July from a year earlier, the Treasury Department said Wednesday, but was headed down for the full 1996 fiscal year.
The monthly shortfall between spending and revenues was $27.1 billion last month, up from $13.6 billion a year earlier.
However, several special factors were at play last year that had the effect of temporarily lowering the monthly deficit in July.

The government moved some military and other spending normally scheduled for July 1 back to June 1995, which reduced July spending requirements. As well, there was a one-time boost to revenues in July 1995 from the sale of broadcast licenses.
Analysts said the long-term trend for the deficit remained positive.
So far in the first 10 months of fiscal 1996, which ends Sept. 30, the total deficit dropped 25.6 percent to $102.1 billion from $137.2 billion in the comparable first 10 months of fiscal 1995.
The Clinton administration forecast last month that the full fiscal 1996 deficit will drop to $117 billion from $163.9 billion for the full 1995 fiscal year.

Kathleen Stephansen, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette Securities Corp. in New York, said the July deficit figure was "very benign and fits well with the approximate $120 billion total set for the full year."

She added that a relatively strong economy has created brisk revenues through taxation for the government, as has a runup in stock market prices this year, which generated profits that are subject to taxes.
